content: beaded socks pattern contributed by trish greydanus materials required 1 ball #10 white cotton crochet thread such as south maid available at wal-mart 60 tri-beads plastic craft beads with three points available at michael s craft store wal-mart 1 pair bobby socks cuff turns down socks with a little lycra not spandex maintain their elasticity and look good longer 1 crochet needle size 3 0-3 5 1 thread beads onto needle with a darning needle that fits through the hole of the bead you will need about 25 beads for a newborn sock 50 for a pair up to 70 beads for a large pair of socks 2 starting at the center back of the sock edge insert needle to middle and pull up a loop catching both threads together chain stitch 3 times once this has been done the thread is secure and you can now drop the yarn end 3 pull a bead up to your work yarn over and pull through loop on hook with the bead in-between chain 3 4 count 3 or 4 stitches over insert hook and pull a loop thr jjk l jl ough make a single_crochet 5 *chain 3 add another bead chain 3 single_crochet into sock 3 or 4 stitches over * repeat around the circle 6 to finish single_crochet into the same place that you started your first stitch then single_crochet 2 times on the first branch of the first chain cut your thread pull the end through the loop darn the starting and ending bits of thread into the chain with a needle you re done no go ahead and make some little girls and probably their moms very happy these socks can be laundered normally washer and dryer however the beads will get banged around by the dryer and eventually get less shiny the first wash shrinks the cotton thread and makes the stitches tighter so that even when the thread is cut it will rarely ravel i have had parents worried about the beads being pulled off or bitten off if a child was diligent enough and had sharp enough teeth they could work their way through the thread however i have made about 200 pairs of these socks i used to sell them at craft fairs and i gave them away to friends for years and i never had anyone tell me a kid got them to unravel or got a bead off i hope you have as much fun making these as i have throughout the years
